France Tax System Guide 2026

France has one of the most complex tax systems in Europe with progressive income tax rates, a unique family quotient system, and high social charges.

2026 French Income Tax Brackets

Tax Rate Income per Part
0%‚Ç¨0 - ‚Ç¨11,509
11%‚Ç¨11,510 - ‚Ç¨29,344
30%‚Ç¨29,345 - ‚Ç¨83,590
41%‚Ç¨83,591 - ‚Ç¨179,506
45%‚Ç¨179,507+

Quotient Familial (Family Quotient) System

How it works:

Income is divided by the number of "parts" based on family composition. Tax is calculated on this divided amount, then multiplied back. This significantly reduces tax for families with children.

  • Single: 1 part
  • Married/PACS: 2 parts
  • 1st child: +0.5 parts
  • 2nd child: +0.5 parts
  • 3rd+ children: +1 part each

Example: Married couple with 2 kids = 2 + 0.5 + 0.5 = 3 parts

Dividend Taxation (2026)

Option 1: Flat Tax (PFU - Pr√©l√®vement Forfaitaire Unique):

  • Total: 30% (12.8% income tax + 17.2% social charges)
  • Simple, automatic
  • Best for high earners

Option 2: Progressive Scale:

  • Add to regular income (with 40% abatement)
  • Taxed at marginal rate (up to 45%)
  • + 17.2% social charges
  • Better for low earners

Social Charges (Pr√©l√®vements Sociaux)

Charge Rate
CSG (Social Security)9.2%
CRDS (Debt Repayment)0.5%
Pr√©l√®vement de solidarit√©7.5%
Total17.2%

Applied to investment income (dividends, interest, capital gains)

Freelancer vs Employee in France

Aspect Freelancer (Auto-entrepreneur) Employee (Salari√©)
Income Tax Same progressive rates Same progressive rates
Social Charges ~22% of revenue (simplified) ~23% (employee) + 45% (employer)
Simplification Micro-BNC option (simplified) Withholding at source
Revenue Limit ‚Ç¨77,700 (services) / ‚Ç¨188,700 (goods) No limit

Auto-Entrepreneur (Micro-Enterprise) Regime

Simplified tax regime for small businesses:

  • Services: Revenue up to ‚Ç¨77,700/year
  • Goods: Revenue up to ‚Ç¨188,700/year
  • Social charges: 21.2% (services) or 12.3% (goods)
  • Income tax: Optional 1.7% (services) or 1% (goods) - replaces progressive tax
  • No VAT: Below threshold (franchise en base)

Important French Tax Deadlines

  • Income Tax Declaration: May-June (online)
  • Pr√©l√®vement √† la source: Monthly withholding
  • Property Tax (Taxe fonci√®re): October 15
  • Wealth Tax (IFI): June (if assets > ‚Ç¨1.3M)

Common French Tax Deductions

  • CSG: 6.8% of 9.2% is deductible from income
  • Pension contributions: Fully deductible
  • Childcare costs: 50% credit (max ‚Ç¨1,150/child)
  • Home employment: 50% credit (max ‚Ç¨12,000)
  • Charitable donations: 66% reduction (up to 20% of income)

France vs Other European Countries

Country Top Rate Social Charges
France45%17.2% (investments)
Germany45%~40% (employees)

Netherlands49.5%Built into tax

Pros and Cons of French Tax System

Pros:

  • Family-friendly quotient familial reduces tax for families
  • Excellent public services and healthcare
  • Auto-entrepreneur regime is simple
  • Many tax credits available (childcare, home help)
  • Strong social safety net

Cons:

  • Very high marginal rates (up to 45%)
  • High social charges (17.2% on investments)
  • Complex tax system
  • Wealth tax (IFI) above ‚Ç¨1.3M
  • Total tax burden can exceed 60% for high earners

Tips for Freelancers in France

  • Consider auto-entrepreneur regime if revenue is below thresholds
  • Choose between micro-regime and r√©el simplifi√© carefully
  • Maximize pension contributions (deductible)
  • Consider SARL or EURL structure if profits exceed ‚Ç¨50k
  • Keep detailed records of all business expenses
  • Use flat tax (PFU) for dividends if in high bracket
  • Set aside 40-50% of income for taxes and social charges

Important: French tax law is extremely complex with many special cases and deductions. This calculator provides estimates only. Always consult with a qualified expert-comptable (French accountant) for accurate tax planning and compliance with Direction G√©n√©rale des Finances Publiques (DGFiP) requirements.
